title: The future of sanitation: 10 years of reinventing the toilet
author: Ryan Bell Feature Writer; Bill; Melinda Gates Foundation
description: We already have the breakthrough technologies needed to provide safe and affordable sanitation services to the billions of people who are at risk of waste-borne diseases. Building markets and attracting businesses to this emerging sector are the next big challenges.
cleaned_text: Read next [De-throning "The Throne" at the Reinvent the Toilet Expo in Beijing, China](/ideas/articles/toilet-sanitation-china-beijing-innovation) The flush toilet hasn't changed much since it was invented in 1596 by Sir John Harington. (Yes, the inventor of "The John" was named John. See also: Thomas Crapper.) Sure, there have been other advancements - waste treatment plants, underground sewers, septic systems - but these complicated, expensive, and hard-to-manage technologies don't do much good in developing countries where 950 million people still have to defecate outdoors. [ Our work with Water, Sanitation & Hygiene ](/our-work/programs/global-growth-and-opportunity/water-sanitation-and-hygiene) The foundation focuses on accelerating innovations in non-sewered sanitation technology and service delivery, particularly in densely populated areas of South Asia and sub-Saharan Africa. [ Reinvent the Toilet Challenge: A brief history ](/our-work/programs/global-growth-and-opportunity/water-sanitation-and-hygiene/reinvent-the-toilet-challenge-and-expo) Learn more about the history of the Reinvent the Toilet Challenge and the foundation's collaborations with global innovators, development banks, corporate partners, sanitation utilities, and governments.
